conclusion: Radius of the hemisphere, R; Distance between point D and line AC is sqrt(3)/2*R; Distance DE = sqrt(2)*R; Speed of light in a vacuum is c
O is the center of the hemisphere; D is at a vertical distance sqrt(3)/2*R from AC; DE = sqrt(2)*R forms a right triangle with OD and the horizontal distance from O to the projection of D on AC
OD = R (radius of the hemisphere); Vertical component from O to D is sqrt(3)/2*R; Horizontal component from O to the projection of D on AC is sqrt(R^2 - (sqrt(3)/2*R)^2) = 1/2*R
Angle of incidence i: cos i = adjacent/hypotenuse = (1/2*R)/R = 1/2; i = cos^(-1)(1/2) = 60 degrees
Snell's Law at point D: n1*sin i = n2*sin r; Here, n1 = 1 (refractive index of air), i = 60 degrees, and n2 is the refractive index of the medium

Using the Law of Cosines in triangle ODE: DE^2 = OD^2 + OE^2 - 2*OD*OE*cos(angle DOE); (sqrt(2)*R)^2 = R^2 + R^2 - 2*R^2*cos(angle DOE); 2*R^2 = 2*R^2*(1 - cos(angle DOE)); cos(angle DOE) = 0 implies angle DOE = 90 degrees; Thus, r = 30 degrees
Using Snell's Law: 1*sin 60 degrees = n2*sin 30 degrees; sqrt(3)/2 = n2*1/2; n2 = sqrt(3)
The refractive index of the transparent medium is sqrt(3)
